text:
Initials as first names and religious names — Hari, Om and Jagdish, for instance — are most common among older men, while Rahul, Rohit and Amit are popular names for younger men.

The lack of a traditional culture of first names and last names, unlike in the West, poses unique challenges both to citizens and authorities.

Muslim men, for example, routinely use “Mohammed” as a prefix, which becomes their first name in government forms, leading to the high number of Mohammeds in Delhi. Mohammed Aslam (80), a retired Assistant Commissioner of Customs, who lives in Preet Vihar, though originally from the Jamia Masjid area, describes himself as a “Pakka Dilliwalla” (true-blue Delhiite).

Mr. Aslam writes “Mohammed” as his first name and “Aslam” as his last name in government forms, though Aslam is the name friends and family know him by. His father was M. Yamin, and his sons are M. Rehan Aslam and M. Salman Aslam, the M standing for “Mohammed”.

In addition to the challenges posed by complicated naming conventions across the country, Election Commission officials frequently err while entering details, former Election Commissioner S.Y. Quraishi says. Mr. Quraishi says he uses the expanded form of his initials, Shahabuddin Yakub, as his first name on his voter ID card, because he is known more commonly by those and to avoid errors. He has reasons to be cautious: his son-in-law’s name has been incorrectly entered on his voter ID card, in addition to his father’s name.

Visit thehindu.com/data to search for your name.
title: Most popular names in Delhi
